laws.name: Murphy's Law
laws.description: Anything that can go wrong will go wrong.
laws.explanation: In governance, always prepare for worst-case scenarios and have contingency plans.

laws.name: Pareto Principle
laws.description: 80% of effects come from 20% of causes (80/20 Rule).
laws.explanation: Focus your resources on the most impactful areas to maximize efficiency.

laws.name: Occam's Razor
laws.description: The simplest explanation is usually the correct one.
laws.explanation: When analyzing complex situations, start with the most straightforward hypothesis.

laws.name: Parkinson's Law
laws.description: Work expands to fill the time available for its completion.
laws.explanation: Set tight deadlines to prevent bureaucratic inefficiency.

laws.name: Peter Principle
laws.description: People in hierarchies rise to their level of incompetence.
laws.explanation: Promote based on skills needed for the new position, not just performance in the current role.

laws.name: Hanlon's Razor
laws.description: Never attribute to malice what can be adequately explained by incompetence.
laws.explanation: When analyzing failures, consider incompetence before conspiracy.

laws.name: Hofstadter's Law
laws.description: It always takes longer than you expect, even when you take into account Hofstadter's Law.
laws.explanation: Always add buffer time to project timelines, especially for complex governmental initiatives.

laws.name: Law of Diminishing Returns
laws.description: After a certain point, additional inputs yield progressively smaller outputs.
laws.explanation: Recognize when additional resources will no longer provide proportional benefits.

laws.name: Gresham's Law
laws.description: Bad money drives out good money.
laws.explanation: In economics, lower quality tends to displace higher quality if they're valued the same.

laws.name: Sturgeon's Law
laws.explanation: Be highly selective in policy implementation; most ideas won't be excellent.

laws.name: Amara's Law
laws.description: We tend to overestimate the effect of a technology in the short run and underestimate it in the long run.
laws.explanation: Make technology policies with long-term vision, not just immediate impact.

laws.name: Goodhart's Law
laws.description: When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure.
laws.explanation: Don't let metrics become the goal; they should reflect real progress.

laws.name: Matthew Principle
laws.description: The rich get richer and the poor get poorer.
laws.explanation: Be aware of how policies might amplify existing inequalities.

laws.name: Moore's Law
laws.description: Computing power doubles approximately every two years.
laws.explanation: Plan for exponential technological change in long-term policy.

laws.name: Chekhov's Gun
laws.description: If you show a gun in the first act, it must be fired by the third.
laws.explanation: Every policy introduced should have a purpose and eventual impact.
